Murtaugh, Tim (@TimMurtaugh). â€œThis, obviously, is fake, and a recurring lie the trolls roll out a lot.â€ Twitter. 15 Jun 2020.

â€œThis posting has been flagged for removal.â€ Tulsa.Craislist.org. Accessed 18 Jun 2020.

articles.title: Gifting a Folded Flag Isnâ€™t â€˜Only For Fallen Veteransâ€™
articles.text:
Quick Take

Headlines on social media misleadingly suggest that House Speaker Nancy Pelosi violated a military tradition when she gave a folded flag to the brother of George Floyd. A folded flag is not â€œReserved Only For Fallen Veterans,â€ as one headline claims. Members of Congress routinely present flags that have flown over the U.S. Capitol as gifts.

Full Story

Philonise Floyd â€” the brother of George Floyd, who was killed in police custody in Minneapolis in late May â€” testified before the House Judiciary Committee on June 10 during a hearing on police practices and law enforcement accountability.

During Philonise Floydâ€™s visit to the Capitol, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi gifted him a folded, encased U.S. flag â€” as a photo posted on her official Facebook and Twitter accounts shows.

â€œPhilonise Floydâ€™s heart-wrenching testimony to the House Judiciary Committee left its mark on us all. May this flag, which flew over the Capitol on the day of his brotherâ€™s murder, serve as a symbol of our shared commitment to securing justice for George and all victims of police violence,â€ her Facebook post said.

Headlines that circulated on social media in the days after, however, misleadingly suggested that Pelosiâ€™s act trampled on a tradition that reserved the gifting of a folded flag only for military families.

The conspiracy theory website InfoWars, in a June 15 story that was republished by teaparty.org, declared: â€œPelosi Gifts George Floydâ€™s Brother Folded American Flag Reserved Only For Fallen Veterans.â€

A headline on NeonNettle.com on June 16 echoed the claim: â€œPelosi Gifts George Floydâ€™s Brother Folded American Flag Meant for Fallen Military.â€ The website later corrected its story.

The InfoWars story goes on to claim that â€œ[f]olded American flags are traditionally presented by the U.S. government to families of fallen veterans during military funeralsâ€ and cites â€œspecific criteria necessary to receive a folded American flagâ€ from the U.S. Veterans Affairs website. It claims Floydâ€™s family â€œdoes not fall into the listed criteria of eligible recipients.â€

There are indeed criteria for those eligible to receive burial flags from Veterans Affairs; the flags are provided at no cost for the funeral of veterans and typically are given to the next-of-kin as a keepsake afterward.

But thereâ€™s nothing that precludes Pelosi, or any other American citizen, from gifting a flag â€” or folding it.

â€œThere are no prescriptive rules saying you canâ€™t give a flag to anyone,â€ said Scot Guenter, senior director of the Flag Research Center and professor emeritus of American Studies at San Jose State University. â€œThe whole point of the American flag is that we donâ€™t live in a society that says you canâ€™t use the flag.â€

Guenter, who wrote the book, â€œThe American Flag, 1777-1924: Cultural Shifts from Creation to Codification,â€ also told us in a phone interview that folding a flag is a sign of respect for it.

There is also no mention in the U.S. â€œFlag Code,â€ whose provisions Guenter said are â€œrules of etiquette,â€ of who is allowed to gift a flag.

â€œWhile the Department of Veterans Affairs provides a casket flag for all honorable veterans and the military service provides them for active-duty service members upon their death, the U.S. Flag Code does not prohibit or limit a flag draping the coffin to any specific group,â€ John Raughter, a spokesman for the American Legion, a veterans association, told us in an email. â€œTraditionally though, as the flag is provided for veterans and active-duty service members, it has come to represent a veteran funeral rite.â€

Raughter added that â€œthere is no rule about who may receive a flag as a gift. We encourage the display of the flag of the United States by all citizens of the United States. Now while there is no rule for it, traditionally a flag is folded into a triangle when it is not flown and may be stored in a presentation case if a particular flag has special meaning.â€

â€œSo presenting someone with a flag, folded into a triangle and placed into a display case is an honorable way of presenting and maintaining the flag of the United States,â€ he said.

Flags that are flown over the Capitol â€” as was the case with the one given to Philonise Floyd â€” are, in fact, routinely requested by the offices of members of Congress through the Capitol Flag Program, which started in the 1930s.

The program, under the Architect of the Capitol, allows members of the public to purchase such flags through House and Senate offices; many members of Congress have instructions on their websites for ordering a flag for any occasion. The Architect of the Capitol â€œfulfills on average more than 100,000 flag requests from Members of Congress annually, with the number of requests and the popularity of the Capitol Flag Program growing steadily each year,â€ according to the programâ€™s website.

And, according to the House Membersâ€™ Congressional Handbook, members can use such flags as official gifts.

â€œU.S. flags flown over the Capitol for official presentation as a gift, including the flag flying fee, are reimbursable,â€ the handbook says. â€œSuch flags must be for the personal use of or display by the recipient (examples may include, but are not limited to: flags presented at a building dedication for which the Member secured official funding, a flag presented to the family of a fallen soldier, flags presented for exceptional public distinction, etc,).â€

So nothing in the handbook, either, limits membersâ€™ gifting of flags flown over the Capitol only to military families.

In December 2016, former Rep. Dennis Ross, a Republican from Florida, gave a folded, framed flag that had flown over the Capitol to a new school in Davenport, Florida. And the next year, Republican Rep. Roger Williams of Texas gifted two folded, encased flags from the Capitol to two new schools in his district.

Update, June 19: We updated this article to reflect that NeonNettle.com has corrected its story.

Editorâ€™s note: FactCheck.org is one of several organizations working with Facebook to debunk misinformation shared on social media. Our previous stories can be found here.

Sources

â€œBurial Flags Frequently Asked Questions.â€ U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs. Accessed 17 Jun 2020.

â€œCapitol Flag Program.â€ Architect of the Capitol. Accessed 18 Jun 2020.

â€œCitrus Ridge: A Civics Academy Grand Opening.â€ The Ledger. 9 Dec 2016.

Guenter, Scot. Senior director, Flag Research Center. Phone interview with FactCheck.org. 17 Jun 2020.

Martin, Todd. â€œâ€˜This gift represents our countryâ€™: Flags flown at U.S. Capitol arrive in Killeen.â€ Killeen Daily Herald. 15 Dec 2017.

â€œMembersâ€™ Congressional Handbook.â€ House Committee on House Administration. Accessed 18 Jun 2020.

Pelosi, Nancy (@NancyPelosi). â€œPhilonise Floydâ€™s heart-wrenching testimony to the House Judiciary Committee left its mark on us all. May this flag, which flew over the Capitol on the day of his brotherâ€™s murder, serve as a symbol of our shared commitment to securing justice for George and all victims of police violence.â€ Facebook. 10 Jun 2020.

â€œOversight Hearing on Policing Practices and Law Enforcement Accountability.â€ House Committee on the Judiciary. 10 Jun 2020.

Raugher, John. Spokesman, American Legion. Email to FactCheck.org. 18 Jun 2020.

articles.title: Azar, Trump Mislead on FDAâ€™s Hydroxychloroquine Decision
articles.text:
In a meeting at the White House, Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar left the misleading impression that the Food and Drug Administrationâ€™s decision to revoke its emergency use authorization of hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine for COVID-19 â€œremoves a potential barrierâ€ and makes it easier to access the drugs. The FDAâ€™s action does the opposite.

Following Azarâ€™s lead, President Donald Trump also falsely accused a journalist of asking a â€œvery inaccurately stated questionâ€ about the FDAâ€™s emergency use authorization, or EUA, and continued to point to unscientific anecdotal evidence to insist that hydroxychloroquine is effective against COVID-19, despite growing evidence to the contrary.

The FDA announced on June 15 that it had revoked its EUA for hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine because the drugs are â€œunlikely to be effective in treating COVID-19 for the authorized uses in the EUA,â€ and that the â€œknown and potential benefitsâ€ of the drugs â€œno longer outweighâ€ the risks â€” which can include â€œserious cardiac adverse events and other potential serious side effects.â€

The FDA had issued the EUA back in March to allow adult and some adolescent patients hospitalized with COVID-19 to obtain the drugs from the Strategic National Stockpile â€œwhen clinical trials are not available, or participation is not feasible.â€

But accumulating evidence, including a large randomized controlled trial that the agency cited in its decision, has found that hydroxychloroquine does not help hospitalized COVID-19 patients. Other trials also indicate that the drug does not prevent the disease if given shortly after exposure to the coronavirus.

The political spin began at a June 15 roundtable discussion at the White House when a journalist asked Trump to respond to news of the FDAâ€™s revocation. The reporter paraphrased the agency as saying the drugs were â€œno longer considered reasonable as a useful treatment for COVID.â€

Trump has misleadingly promoted hydroxychloroquine as a potential â€œgame changer,â€ despite its health risks and unproven use as a COVID-19 treatment.

Azar said that the reporterâ€™s question was not â€œquite accurateâ€ because the FDAâ€™s finding only applied to hospitalized patients. He then proceeded to suggest that revoking the EUA was a good thing because it removes a â€œsignificant misunderstandingâ€ that the drug could only be used in a hospital setting.

The secretary stressed that the drug can still be prescribed for off-label use to treat COVID-19, saying the FDAâ€™s decision â€œactually removes a potential barrier to that.â€

Azar, June 15: At this point, hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine are just like any other approved drug in the United States. They may be used in hospital, they may be used in out-patient, they may be used at home â€” all subject to a doctorâ€™s prescription. In fact, the FDAâ€™s removal of the emergency use authorization takes away what had been a significant misunderstanding by many that had made people think that somehow it could only be used in a hospital setting. And weâ€™ve tried to make that clear throughout. Itâ€™s a drug. Itâ€™s approved in the United States. Has been for decades. If a doctor wishes to prescribe it, working with a patient, they may prescribe it for any purpose that they wish to do so. And this actually removes a potential barrier to that. Trump: So it actually un-complicates it â€” Azar: It does. Trump: â€” in a way. And I think thatâ€™s probably â€” your question was a very inaccurately stated question. Reporter: No, I didnâ€™t mean to â€” I didnâ€™t mean to pose it inaccurately. I believe what it said specifically was that itâ€™s no longer reasonable to consider it an appropriate treatment. Azar: Only in the hospital. It said the data in the hospital setting was not supported. We continue to study in outpatient settings, as well as preventive. That data is not yet in.

While itâ€™s true that the FDAâ€™s decision only pertains to hospitalized patients, the reporterâ€™s phrasing is very similar to that used in the agencyâ€™s own revocation letter.

â€œFDA has concluded that, based on this new information and other information discussed in the attached memorandum, it is no longer reasonable to believe that oral formulations of HCQ and CQ may be effective in treating COVID-19, nor is it reasonable to believe that the known and potential benefits of these products outweigh their known and potential risks,â€ wrote FDA Chief Scientist Denise M. Hinton.

Rachel Sachs, a Washington University in St. Louis law professor, told us in a phone interview that the â€œreasonableâ€ language, which both the reporter and the FDA used, is part of the statute governing how the FDA can issue EUAs.

â€œOne of the things that the FDA has to find when it grants an EUA is that itâ€™s reasonable to believe that the drug in question is effective for the treatment of the condition,â€ she said. â€œAnd so what the FDA is saying now is that based on the weight of the evidence, itâ€™s no longer reasonable to believe that hydroxychloroquine is effective for the treatment of COVID.â€

In the letter, the agency toggles between statements that are specific to hospitalized patients and others that are more general. For instance, the FDA says that upon a second review of the in vitro studies that first suggested chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine might have an ability to combat the coronavirus, it now believes the suggested doses â€œare unlikely to produce an antiviral effect.â€

It also notes that the earlier studies that found the drugs might decrease the amount of virus patients shed â€œhave not been consistently replicated,â€ and that a randomized controlled trial that more rigorously tested the idea found no difference between the proportion of those taking hydroxychloroquine and those getting the standard of care in testing negative for the virus.

Thatâ€™s in addition to national guidelines that now do not recommend the use of hydroxychloroquine or chloroquine in hospitalized COVID-19 patients outside of a clinical trial, including the National Institutes of Health guidelines, which recommend against the use of the drugs outside of a trial.

Several experts expressed bafflement that Azar â€” and then Trump â€” would object to the reporterâ€™s question.

â€œThatâ€™s exactly what the FDA said,â€ said Dr. Neil Schluger, a pulmonologist and critical care specialist at Columbia University who has studied hydroxychloroquine for the treatment of COVID-19. â€œAzarâ€™s being very misleading in that statement.â€

â€œI thought the reporterâ€™s question was perfect,â€ said Holly Fernandez Lynch, a professor of medical ethics at the University of Pennsylvania with expertise in FDA regulation. â€œIf Azar was doing his job as a public health official, he wouldnâ€™t have chided the reporter for how he asked the question.â€

FDA Decision Doesnâ€™t Remove â€˜Potential Barrierâ€™

Perhaps more critically, experts balked at Azarâ€™s suggestion that removing the EUA was lifting a â€œpotential barrierâ€ on hydroxychloroquineâ€™s use, when in fact, the move reduces access to the drug by eliminating the option of getting it from the national stockpile.

â€œHeâ€™s somehow implying that the EUA made people think you could only use this to treat COVID-19 for hospitalized patients, and now that theyâ€™ve removed the EUA, you could use it to treat COVID patients anywhere,â€ Schluger said of hydroxychloroquine in a phone interview. â€œItâ€™s exactly the opposite of that.â€

Azar is correct to say that because chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are FDA-approved to treat other conditions, including malaria â€” and in the case of hydroxychloroquine, rheumatoid diseases â€” they can be prescribed to COVID-19 patients in whatâ€™s called off-label prescribing.

But that has always been true. The EUA never changed that, and the revocation also does not change that.

â€œThe EUA had no impact on whether physicians could prescribe the drug off-label, whether patients could receive it off-label,â€ said Sachs. â€œIt just made it easier for hospital-based providers to obtain the drug from the stockpile and to administer it to their patients.â€

Itâ€™s useful to consider exactly what the initial EUA did in the first place. As Fernandez Lynch explained, the goal was to provide a supply of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine from the national stockpile, based on the limited evidence at the time that the drugs might work against the coronavirus.

While chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine are drugs that can be prescribed off-label, the specific chloroquine tablets donated to the stockpile were not actually FDA-approved for any use. On top of that, interstate commerce laws prevent distribution of drugs for unapproved uses, which meant that both drugs could not be legally dispensed from the national stockpile for COVID-19.

To make that distribution legal, the FDA needed to issue an EUA, which the agency decided to limit to hospitalized patients outside of clinical trials.

Azarâ€™s argument appears to be that that specification confused people, leading some to think that the drug more broadly could only be prescribed to hospitalized patients â€” and that by revoking the entire EUA, that restriction was lifted.

But Sachs said that line of thinking doesnâ€™t hold water.

â€œI certainly have no evidence to support the claim that people believed hydroxychloroquine was only available in the hospital setting, and that now a barrier to its use was removed,â€ she said. â€œSec. Azarâ€™s framing sounds like what the FDA is doing is opening up hydroxychloroquine for broader use. But thatâ€™s actually not whatâ€™s going on â€” theyâ€™re actually restricting one avenue for its use by withdrawing the EUA.â€

Fernandez Lynch agreed, saying it was misleading for Azar to characterize the EUA revocation as a kind of easing on hydroxychloroquine.

â€œWhat they did was take away the EUA because the evidence no longer supported the EUA,â€ she said in a phone interview, adding that it was irresponsible as a public health official not to relay the information that led the FDA to change its mind. â€œInstead he went ahead and emphasized, do whatever you want under off-label prescribing â€” weâ€™re going to leave this up to you.â€

Contrary to Azarâ€™s suggestion that the FDA was making it easier to get chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine for COVID-19 outpatients, the agency already came forward in late April to caution against the use of both drugs outside of hospitals or a clinical trial.

Misleading Research Summaries

During the roundtable, Azar and Trump also gave misleading or incomplete descriptions of the evidence to date about hydroxychloroquine and COVID-19.

As he has done in the past, the president â€” who has claimed to have taken hydroxychloroquine to prevent COVID-19 â€” said he has heard â€œsome great reportsâ€ about the drugs and suggested without evidence that the hospitalized patients who received hydroxychloroquine were going to die anyway.

Trump, June 15: The only place we donâ€™t get necessarily reports are coming out of Alexâ€™s agency or wherever they come from. I donâ€™t understand that, Alex. What is it exactly? Because I have heard â€” Iâ€™ve had so many people that were so thrilled with the results from hydroxy. So, what is that exactly? Azar: Well, at your direction, we continue to study, especially in earlier phase â€” so a lot of the data that has come out that was more negative was people who were quite ill in the hospital. Trump: People that were, like, seriously ill. Like, they werenâ€™t going to make it. â€œLetâ€™s give them a little hydroxy.â€ And then they donâ€™t make it. And they say, â€œOh, wow, maybe the president was wrong.â€ All I know is that weâ€™ve had some tremendous reports. Iâ€™ve had a lot of people tell me that they think it saved their lives.

As Schluger previously told us, the majority of patients in several hydroxychloroquine studies survived, so itâ€™s not the case that hydroxychloroquine has only been given to deathly ill patients.

It is true, however, that nearly all of the studies have been done in hospitalized patients.

This includes a large randomized controlled trial in the U.K. called RECOVERY that the FDA cited in its EUA revocation decision. Although the full results have not been published, the trial reported on June 5 that hydroxychloroquine did not reduce the risk of death and also did not shorten the hospital stay or offer beneficial effects on other outcomes.

According to a June 5 press release, 25.7% of the 1,542 hospitalized patients who received hydroxychloroquine died after 28 days, whereas 23.5% of the 3,132 patients who were given usual care died â€” a difference that was not statistically significant.

The press release concluded that the results â€œconvincingly rule out any meaningful mortality benefit of hydroxychloroquine in patients hospitalised with COVID-19.â€

From that data, plus other smaller randomized controlled trials and other rigorously performed observational studies, which we have previously reviewed, it does not appear hydroxychloroquine offers any benefit to hospitalized COVID-19 patients.

â€œThe science is pretty straightforward on this,â€ said Schluger. â€œThe data tell a pretty consistent story.â€

On June 17, the World Health Organization announced that given the initial findings from its own trial, the results of the RECOVERY trial and a review of the evidence, it was suspending the hydroxychloroquine arm of its Solidarity trial, which also was evaluating the drug in hospitalized patients.

What is less clear â€” and where Trump and Azar may have a point â€” is that these results donâ€™t necessarily rule out that hydroxychloroquine might still have some effect in milder cases or for COVID-19 prevention.

Some scientists do think itâ€™s plausible that hydroxychloroquine could still work in these instances â€” even if there isnâ€™t yet any evidence that it does.

As Nicholas White, a professor of tropical medicine at the University of Oxfordâ€™s Centre for Tropical Medicine and Global Health and Mahidol University in Thailand, told us in an email, itâ€™s â€œ[m]uch easier to prevent infections growing in the bodyâ€ than to get â€œrid of them once they have grown.â€

He is helping to run a multinational randomized controlled trial with upwards of 40,000 participants to test whether chloroquine or hydroxychloroquine can prevent COVID-19 â€” and is concerned that some governmental decisions, including the FDAâ€™s memo, might make it harder to complete the trials that are necessary to definitively say whether the drugs work or not.

The WHO, notably, also cautioned that its suspension decision should not apply to trials testing hydroxychloroquineâ€™s ability to prevent COVID-19 either before or after exposure, or what is called pre- and post-exposure prophylaxis.

Still, Azar didnâ€™t give the whole story when he said that the â€œdata is not yet inâ€ regarding the use of hydroxychloroquine to treat people outside of the hospital or for COVID-19 prevention. While many of these trials are in the works, at least one has reported results â€” and it, too, failed to identify an effect.

The University of Minnesota published the first post-exposure prophylaxis randomized controlled trial of hydroxychloroquine for COVID-19 in the New England Journal of Medicine on June 3. In the double-blind trial, more than 800 volunteers were randomized to receive hydroxychloroquine or a placebo within four days of exposure to someone with confirmed COVID-19. Nearly 12% of hydroxychloroquine participants developed a COVID-19-like illness compared with 14.3% of those getting the placebo â€” a difference that was not significant.

Some scientists argue that more data is needed. They have critiqued the study because it did not confirm COVID-19 infection in the vast majority of people who were exposed and went on to develop the disease â€” an unavoidable problem, given the lack of testing availability at the time. Others, meanwhile, have found the results largely convincing.

Schluger called it a â€œpretty good study,â€ adding, â€œitâ€™s a pretty big study â€” 821 patients â€” a randomized trial, so thatâ€™s a very high standard of evidence.â€

Science magazine reported on June 9 that another post-exposure prevention trial, run out of Barcelona, Spain, did not pick up a protective effect of hydroxychloroquine. The trial included more than 2,300 people who were exposed to the coronavirus and found there was no significant difference among those who received hydroxychloroquine versus the standard care in developing COVID-19. The studyâ€™s lead investigator told Science that the results had been submitted for publication.

University of Minnesota infectious disease specialist Dr. David Boulware, who led the first published prophylaxis trial, said no studies have reported results yet for pre-exposure prophylaxis. Those studies typically involve high-risk health care workers and have been slower to enroll volunteers.

But he said the results of his universityâ€™s trial of hydroxychloroquine in outpatients had been reported to the FDA.

â€œInvestigators from the University of Minnesota conducted a nationwide randomized clinical trial testing hydroxychloroquine for early outpatient treatment of COVID-19,â€ he said in an email, adding that the drug was given within four days of the start of COVID-19 symptoms. â€œThe trialâ€™s final results were shared with FDA on June 11, 2020 as well as with NIH, and the manuscript is presently undergoing scientific peer-review.â€

â€œThere are no positive data supporting hydroxychloroquine having a clinical benefit in humans with coronavirus,â€ said Boulware in response to Azarâ€™s claim that a lot of the â€œmore negativeâ€ data was in very ill hospitalized patients. â€œThe FDA is fully aware of what data do exist for earlier phase treatment.â€

Editorâ€™s note: FactCheck.org does not accept advertising. We rely on grants and individual donations from people like you. Please consider a donation. Credit card donations may be made through our â€œDonateâ€ page. If you prefer to give by check, send to: FactCheck.org, Annenberg Public Policy Center, 202 S. 36th St., Philadelphia, PA 19104.

articles.title: America First Policies/America First Action
articles.text:
Political leanings: Republican/ Pro-President Trump

2018 total spending: $36.4 million

America First Policies is a 501(c)(4) nonprofit devoted to promoting the agenda of President Donald Trump. According to its website, the groupâ€™s main goals are rebuilding infrastructure, creating a strong workforce, reforming trade agreements, cutting taxes and updating regulations to support the Second Amendment right to bear arms.

America First Policies is allied with America First Action, a pro-Trump super PAC that spent $36.4 million in the 2018 cycle.

Six of Trumpâ€™s former campaign aides created America First Policies in January 2017. The groupâ€™s founders include: Brad Parscale, Trumpâ€™s 2020 campaign manager; David Bossie, Trumpâ€™s 2016 deputy campaign manager; Nick Ayers, Vice President Mike Penceâ€™s former chief of staff; Marty Obst, who managed Penceâ€™s gubernatorial campaign in Indiana; and Katrina Pierson, a 2020 campaign adviser for Trump.

Rick Gates, Trumpâ€™s other deputy campaign manager in 2016, also helped create the nonprofit. However, Gates was forced to leave the group in March 2017 because of his ties to Paul Manafort, a former Trump campaign chairman and chief strategist. As we have previously reported, both Manafort and Gates were indicted on charges of money laundering and tax evasion related to their work for a pro-Russia political party in Ukraine.

Gates pleaded guilty to conspiracy and making false statements to federal investigators. Manafort was sentenced to 47 months in prison after being found guilty in August 2018 on five tax fraud charges, one charge of failing to disclose foreign bank accounts and two counts of bank fraud.

The America First Action super PAC affiliated with America First Policies is led by Linda McMahon, who previously served in Trumpâ€™s cabinet as administrator of the Small Business Administration, and Brian O. Walsh, who, prior to joining America First Action, served as the president of the conservative outside groups American Action Network and the Congressional Leadership Fund.

America First Action raised $29 million in the 2018 election cycle and spent $29.3 million on independent expenditures, which are disbursements on communications advocating for or against particular candidates. Most of that, about $28 million, was spent trying to get Republicans elected to Congress. The organization spent more than $3 million opposing Democrat Colin Allred, who beat Republican Pete Sessions in Texasâ€™ 32nd Congressional District and more than $2.8 million opposing Democrat Joe Donnelly, who lost to Mike Braun in Indianaâ€™s Senate race. The group also spent more than $289,000 in support of Arizona Republican Martha McSally, who lost her Senate race to Democrat Krysten Sinema.

So far in 2020, the America First Action super PAC has raised more than $40 million. As of June 18, America First Action has spent more than $14.5 million in independent expenditures against presumptive Democratic Party presidential nominee Joe Biden and $45,000 in support of Trump.

America First Policies has not publicly disclosed its donors to the Federal Election Commission because 501(c)(4) organizations are not required to do so.

articles.title: Trump Wrong on Obama-Biden Actions on Policing
articles.text:
In signing an executive order on policing issues, President Donald Trump falsely claimed former President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden â€œnever even tried to fix this during their eight-year period.â€

In fact, the Obama administration took several steps to address police violence and community trust issues, some of which the Trump administration has dialed back.

In his June 16 remarks, Trump took a further swipe at Obama and Biden, his Democratic opponent in the 2020 election, adding, â€œThe reason they didnâ€™t try is because they had no idea how to do it.â€ The Trump administration clearly disagreed with some of the Obama administration measures. But itâ€™s simply wrong for Trump to claim the prior administration didnâ€™t do anything.

The Biden campaign disputed the claim. Deputy Campaign Manager and Communications Director Kate Bedingfield said in a statement that Trump â€œknows that isnâ€™t true because he has spent the past three years tearing down the very reforms the Obama-Biden Administration pursued.â€ Bedingfield pointed to three initiatives:

The Task Force on 21st Century Policing, which issued recommendations for police departments in a May 2015 report.

The use of consent decrees to get police departments to enact changes regarding constitutional rights violations.

Limits on the transfer of military weapons to police departments.

David Alan Sklansky, professor of law and faculty co-director of the Stanford Criminal Justice Center, told us those are exactly the three initiatives he would cite. â€œAll three of those were significant steps taken to address problems with American policing including but not limited to the use of force and the issue of race in policing,â€ he said.

Sklansky called Trumpâ€™s claim â€œbaselessâ€ and â€œflat-out false.â€

â€œItâ€™s indisputable that the Obama administration did far more to address this issue than the Trump administration,â€ he said, adding that the Trump administration has tried to undo the progress the previous administration had made.

Specifically, the Trump administration limited the use of consent decrees and rolled back Obamaâ€™s restrictions on the transfer of military equipment to local police departments.

Lauren-Brooke Eisen and Spencer P. Boyer, of the Brennan Center for Justice, also cited these three measures in a June 16 post titled â€œWhat the Federal Government Can Do to Help Fix Policing in America.â€ They included one more Obama-era effort: the Collaborative Reform Initiative in the Office of Community Oriented Policing Services, which worked with local law enforcement to evaluate their operations, and recommend and institute changes. That program, too, ended under Trump.

Task Force on 21st Century Policing

On Dec. 18, 2014, Obama signed an executive order to create the Task Force on 21st Century Policing â€œto strengthen community policing and strengthen trust among law enforcement officers and the communities they serve,â€ a White House fact sheet said.

The task force was formed after several violent police incidents involving African Americans, including the 2014 killings of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Missouri, Eric Garner in New York and Tamir Rice in Cleveland. It was chaired by Charles Ramsey, then the commissioner of the Philadelphia Police Department and president of the Major Cities Chiefs Association, and Laurie Robinson, a professor of criminology and law at George Mason University and a former Justice Department official.

In November and December 2014, grand juries decided not to indict the officers in the Brown and Garner cases. In discussing the task force at the time, Obama said Ferguson, where weeks of protests occurred, exposed â€œa simmering distrust that exists between too many police departments and too many communities of color.â€

The task force issued its final report in May 2015, offering recommendations on issues including building trust, community policing, officer training and officer safety. Sklansky told us the task force was â€œa very extensive operation that culminated in a very detailed, very thoughtful report with a lot of specific recommendations, many of which had to do with police violence.â€

Robinson, in a February article published in the ANNALS of the American Academy of Political and Social Science, said the report â€œhad an impact.â€ Several law enforcement groups â€œhave embraced the report,â€ she said, and a think tank researcher said agencies across the country were using it â€œas their playbook.â€

The Brennan Center experts noted that â€œnot nearly enough jurisdictions have heeded the adviceâ€ in that report.

But itâ€™s worth noting, as the Washington Post Fact Checker also did, that Trumpâ€™s executive order reflected the task force recommendations on a few points.

Trumpâ€™s executive order called for the attorney general and secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services to â€œdevelop opportunities to train law enforcement officers with respect to encounters with individuals suffering from impaired mental health, homelessness, and addictionâ€ and â€œto increase the capacity of social workers working directly with law enforcement agencies.â€ The 2015 task force report recommended â€œmultidisciplinary, community team approachesâ€ for â€œresponding to mental health crisis situationsâ€ as well as community problems involving â€œhomelessness, substance abuse, domestic violence, human trafficking, and child abuse.â€

The task force said law enforcement â€œpolicies for training on use of force should emphasize de-escalation and alternatives to arrest or summons in situations where appropriate,â€ while Trumpâ€™s executive order said the administration shall propose legislation that would include â€œtraining and technical assistance required to adopt and implement improved use-of-force policies and procedures, including scenario-driven de-escalation techniques.â€

Consent Decrees

The Obama administrationâ€™s Department of Justice Civil Rights Division conducted â€œpattern or practiceâ€ investigations of police departments focused on whether there were patterns of constitutional rights violations, and then obtained court-enforced consent decrees to get some departments to implement changes.

A Jan. 5, 2017, exit memo by then-Attorney General Loretta Lynch said the DOJ launched 23 such investigations under Obama and â€œis now enforcing 17 agreements with law enforcement agencies across the country, including 14 consent decrees.â€ Those investigations focused on the Ferguson Police Department, as well as agencies in Baltimore, Chicago and other cities.

â€œConsent decrees were a very important initiative to try to bring systemic change to police departments,â€ addressing all forms of policing including use of force, Sklansky said. The Obama administration â€œlaunched more of these investigations than any previous administration.â€

But the Trump administration significantly scaled back that effort. Eisen and Boyer write that on the day he left office, then-Attorney General Jeff Sessions â€œsigned a memo detailing the narrow circumstances under which DOJ can enter into a consent decree. Since President Trump took office, the Justice Department has publicly announced only one pattern-or-practice investigation into a police department.â€

The Nov. 7, 2018, memo said it â€œprovides guidance on the limited circumstances in which such a consent decree may be appropriate; limits the terms for consent decrees and settlement agreements with state and local governmental entitiesâ€ and â€œamends the process for the approval of these mechanisms in cases in which they are permissible.â€

Sessions had criticized the Baltimore consent decree, an agreement reached near the end of the Obama administration but signed by a federal judge in April 2017. Sessions said he had â€œgrave concerns that some provisions of this decree will reduce the lawful powers of the police department and result in a less safe city.â€

Military Weapons

Obama also signed an executive order to create a working group to limit surplus military equipment and supplies that are provided for free to state and local law enforcement agencies under whatâ€™s called the 1033 program.

The administration then adopted the recommendations of the working group, issued in May 2015, creating a â€œprohibited equipment listâ€ â€” which included tracked armored vehicles, grenade launchers and firearms/ammunition of .50 caliber and above â€” and a â€œcontrolled equipment listâ€ â€” including wheeled armored vehicles, riot shields and helmets, and explosives. Police departments could still obtain the equipment in the latter group, but they would have to provide justification for needing it and proper training.

We wrote about this issue in 2017 when Sessions misleadingly cited studies to claim Obama â€œwent too farâ€ and undermined public safety.

On Aug. 28, 2017, Trump issued an executive order rescinding Obamaâ€™s.

Other Efforts

In addition, the Brennan Center experts wrote about the Trump administrationâ€™s curtailing of the Collaborative Reform Initiative in the Office of Community Oriented Policing Services, saying the program â€œhad widespread support from police chiefs across the countryâ€ and allowed the DOJ to work with the cities and avoid litigation.

Sessions scaled back that program in September 2017, saying in a memo, â€œThis is a course correction to ensure that resources go to agencies that require assistance rather than expensive wide-ranging investigative assessments that go beyond the scope of technical assistance and support.â€

At the time, the Washington Post reported that Sessionsâ€™ decision would affect â€œabout 14 police departments nationwide that had either begun receiving public reports from the COPS office or expected to receive such reports soon.â€

In September 2015, the Obama DOJ also announced $23.2 million in grants to 73 local law enforcement agencies to â€œexpand the use of body-worn cameras and explore their impact.â€

In her exit memo, Lynch also touted implicit bias training that the DOJ required of all employees and federal law enforcement agencies.

Clearly, Trump was wrong to claim Obama and Biden â€œnever even tried to fixâ€ issues surrounding police brutality and lack of trust between police departments and the communities they serve. Trump may not agree with some of the measures â€” as evidenced by his eliminating or restricting them â€” but they were indeed efforts aimed directly at these issues.

articles.title: Facebook Post Repeats Flawed Claim on Wuhan Lab Funding
articles.text:
Quick Take

A Facebook post is spreading the false claim that former President Barack Obama gave $3.8 million to a lab in Wuhan, China. The money referenced was actually provided to a U.S. research group. Only $600,000 went to the lab as part of a U.S.-approved collaboration.

Full Story

A post circulating on Facebook is spreading a debunked falsehood about U.S. funding that went to a lab in Wuhan, China â€” the city where the outbreak of the novel coronavirus began â€” as well as a false claim about the origins of the virus.

â€œPresident Trump just announced that the â€˜biologicalâ€™ lab in Wuhan where the COVID-19 virus was created was â€˜fundedâ€™ by President Barak Hussein Obama in 2015 to the tune of $3,800,000 American dollars,â€ the post reads. It further claims, falsely, that â€œthis fact directly links Obama to all 150,000 deaths around the world!â€

The post, a text image, was uploaded as early as April but is continuing to spread.

First of all, the suggestion that the virus was â€œcreatedâ€ is a baseless conspiracy theory that we first wrote about in February. Weâ€™ve continued to debunk similar claims.

The postâ€™s main claim about U.S. funding is one that weâ€™ve also previously addressed.

The $3.8 million figure refers actually to a $3.4 million grant that the National Institutes of Health awarded to a U.S.-based group, EcoHealth Alliance. That group was studying the risk of future emergence of coronaviruses from bats and first received the grant in 2014.

Of that amount, EcoHealth gave $600,000 to the Wuhan Institute of Virology â€” a collaborator on the project that was pre-approved by NIH and the State Department â€” Robert Kessler, EcoHealthâ€™s spokesperson, previously told us.

The grant was renewed in 2019 for another five years, Kessler said â€” and EcoHealth received $292,161 that year (part of the total $3.4 million it received). NIH terminated the grant in April.

President Donald Trump has also previously floated an unsupported claim that the amount received by the Wuhan lab was even higher â€” $7.5 million â€” and that he â€œended it.â€ But as we explained before, the grant that was discontinued was EcoHealthâ€™s and the portion that went to the lab was $600,000.

A Fox News story in April also made reference to another $3.4 million NIH grant â€” regarding a behavioral study â€” and suggested that some of the funding may have gone to the Wuhan lab. (The story noted, however, that it was â€œnot clear exactly how much U.S. funding went directly to the Wuhan Institute of Virology because it worked in collaboration with other institutions on the projects funded by the American grants.â€)

But the recipient of that other grant, which was renewed this year â€” Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory in New York â€” told us that wasnâ€™t the case.

â€œ[B]ased on CSHLâ€™s records for its NIH R01 award MH101214, there is nothing to indicate that any money from this grant was provided to the Wuhan Institute of Virology,â€ Dagnia Zeidlickis, the labâ€™s vice president of communications, told us in an email.



Editorâ€™s note: FactCheck.org is one of several organizations working with Facebook to debunk misinformation shared on social media. Our previous stories can be found here.

Sources

Fichera, Angelo, et. al. â€œThe Falsehoods of the â€˜Plandemicâ€™ Video.â€ FactCheck.org. 8 May 2020.

Kessler, Robert. Spokesman, EcoHealth Alliance. Email to FactCheck.org. 8 May 2020.

McDonald, Jessica. â€œBaseless Conspiracy Theories Claim New Coronavirus Was Bioengineered.â€ FactCheck.org. 7 Feb 2020.

â€œRegarding NIH Termination of Coronavirus Research Funding.â€ Press release, EcoHealth Alliance. 28 Apr 2020.

Robertson, Lori. â€œTrump Spreads Distorted Claim on Wuhan Lab Funding.â€ FactCheck.org. 15 May 2020.

U.S. National Institutes of Health. â€œProject Information | 2R01AI110964-06.â€ Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools. Accessed 15 Jun 2020.

U.S. National Institutes of Health. â€œProject Information | 2R01MH101214-06.â€ Research Portfolio Online Reporting Tools. Accessed 15 Jun 2020.

Zeidlickis, Dagnia. Vice president of communications, Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory. Email to FactCheck.org. 16 Jun 2020.

articles.title: Penceâ€™s False Claims About Trumpâ€™s Handling of Coronavirus
articles.text:
During a visit to Iowa, Vice President Mike Pence made several false claims about President Donald Trumpâ€™s handling of the novel coronavirus pandemic.

In remarks to employees of Winnebago Industries in Forest City, Iowa, June 16, Pence said Trump â€œshut down all travel from China.â€ The president did impose travel restrictions on China but did not shut down all travel.

Pence also said that Trump took the action before there had been a single case of the disease in this country. That also is not accurate.

And finally, Pence said that Trumpâ€™s action gave the United States time to set up its response to the pandemic. But some disease experts say the Trump administration did not use that time effectively.

Pence, June 16: You know, before we had a single coronavirus case in this country, this president shut down all travel from China. It bought us invaluable time to stand up our national response.

There have been more than 2.1 million cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus, in the United States and more than 116,000 deaths, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

The novel coronavirus outbreak began in Wuhan, China, late last year. Health and Human Services Secretary Alex Azar announced the China travel restrictions on Jan. 31. The restrictions, which went into effect Feb. 2, prohibited non-U.S. citizens who had traveled to China within the previous two weeks from entering the U.S.

But the new rules didnâ€™t apply to U.S. citizens, permanent residents and their immediate family members.

A New York Times story on April 4 found that nearly 40,000 people had flown on direct flights from China to the United States in the two months after the travel restrictions went into effect. So travel from China had hardly been â€œshut down.â€

Trump, too, has frequently overstated the extent of his travel restrictions. For example, as we have written, in April he three times incorrectly referred to a â€œtravel banâ€ and on another occasion said he had â€œclosed the borderâ€ with China.

Pence also was off-base in saying the travel restrictions were imposed before the first case of COVID-19 was detected in the United States. In fact, the first reported case was confirmed 11 days earlier, on Jan. 20. The infected man, a resident of Snohomish County, Washington, in his 30s, developed symptoms after returning from a trip to the area around Wuhan.

There were four confirmed cases as of Jan. 31, when the travel restrictions were announced, and nine cases two days later, when they took effect, according to the CDC.

Trump has said accurately that no one had died in the U.S. when his administration announced the travel restrictions. The first reported coronavirus death in this country was disclosed on Feb. 29.

Pence said the travel restrictions â€œbought us invaluable time to stand up our national response.â€ But experts have faulted Trump for failing to use that time to act more aggressively in dealing with the pandemic. In fact, between Jan. 22 and March 10, Trump frequently minimized the impact of the coronavirus.

For example, Trump said on Feb. 26, â€œAnd again, when you have 15 people, and the 15 within a couple of days is going to be down to close to zero, thatâ€™s a pretty good job weâ€™ve done.â€

And as late as March 10, the president said, â€œAnd weâ€™re prepared, and weâ€™re doing a great job with it. And it will go away. Just stay calm. It will go away.â€ The following day, the World Health Organization declared the global coronavirus outbreak a pandemic.

Asked whether the restrictions had indeed â€œbought us invaluable time,â€ Marc Lipsitch, professor of epidemiology and director of the Center for Communicable Disease Dynamics at the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, told us in an email: â€œI do think it bought us a bit of time, though it was not very well or effectively implemented. The White House was in denial for January and most of February, and then took a laissez-faire attitude for much of March, squandering that time.â€

One of the keys to dealing with a pandemic is widespread testing. In an ad in May, the Trump campaign misleadingly boasted that the president had taken â€œfast actionâ€ in regard to testing. But several infectious disease experts also disputed that assertion.

â€œThe United States has lagged nearly every developed country in ramping up testing, and the slow action is one reason why we have the worst epidemic in the world and are discussing reopening when it is not safe to do so, while other countries have used testing as a centerpiece of their strategy to reduce cases to a point where reopening is much more appropriate,â€ Lipsitch, told us for a previous story. â€œThe lack of testing has been not only a public health catastrophe in the US, but also is a direct cause of our economic suffering.â€

And Paul A. Offit, director of the Vaccine Education Center and an attending physician in the Division of Infectious Diseases at Childrenâ€™s Hospital of Philadelphia, told us in an email at the time: â€œWe need only look at other countries (like South Korea, Germany, Singapore, New Zealand and others) to see what rapid testing and identification can do to slow down spread of this virus. South Korea had done 150,000 tests before we had done 500. The fact that we have more deaths per million in the population than many other developed countries is a testament to our slow response to this virus.â€

Among the factors slowing down the testing were the CDCâ€™s problems in producing tests and delays in enlisting hospital labs and commercial labs in developing tests, according to Tom Frieden, who was head of the CDC during the Obama administration. In April, we documented the extent and causes of the testing delays.

articles.title: Biden on Economic Growth and Trumpâ€™s Tax Cuts
articles.text:
Former Vice President Joe Biden wrongly says â€œmost of the conservative think tanks,â€ including the Heritage Foundation, agree that the tax cuts championed by President Donald Trump â€œgenerated virtually no growth at all.â€

There are many economists who might agree with Biden, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, that the tax cuts have not generated much, if any, economic growth, but most conservative think tanks, including the Heritage Foundation, are not among them.

The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, passed by Congress and signed by Trump in December 2017, was billed by Republicans as a catalyst to accelerate economic growth and in turn, to create more jobs and higher wages. The law lowered many individual tax rates, nearly doubled the standard deduction, eliminated personal exemptions and increased child tax credits, among other changes. It also cut the top corporate tax rate from 35% to 21%. It is expected to add $1 trillion to $2 trillion to the federal debt over 10 years.

In an open letter to Congress in November 2017, more than 100 economists in support of the tax cuts predicted the tax cuts would â€œignite our economy with levels of growth not seen in generations.â€

A Congressional Research Service review of the first-year impact of the law, however, did not find evidence of â€œlarge effects particularly in the short run.â€

CRS, May 22, 2019: In 2018, gross domestic product (GDP) grew at 2.9%, about the Congressional Budget Officeâ€™s (CBOâ€™s) projected rate published in 2017 before the tax cut. On the whole, the growth effects tend to show a relatively small (if any) first-year effect on the economy. Although growth rates cannot indicate the tax cutâ€™s effects on GDP, they tend to rule out very large effects particularly in the short run. Although investment grew significantly, the growth patterns for different types of assets do not appear to be consistent with the direction and size of the supply-side incentive effects one would expect from the tax changes. This potential outcome may raise questions about how much longer-run growth will result from the tax revision.

Last week, Biden seized on the GDP growth figures highlighted in the CRS report to argue that the TCJA has â€œgenerated virtually no growth at all.â€ And, Biden added, that is according to conservative think tanks, including the Heritage Foundation.

â€œImagine if we had that $2 trillion tax cut and we hadnâ€™t wasted it on the wealthy, that generated virtually no growth at all,â€ Biden said on â€œThe Daily Show with Trevor Noahâ€ on June 10. â€œNo growth at all, according to most of the conservative think tanks.â€

â€œAnd imagine if we had that $2 trillion tax cut that he promoted and got passed for the wealthy, even places like the Heritage Foundation said that didnâ€™t grow the economy. $2 trillion,â€ Biden said on June 11 during a roundtable meeting in Philadelphia on opening the economy. â€œImagine if we had it right now, to focus on the things that can build a new economy, invest in everything from teleconference, into providing for the kind of health.â€

What Economists Say

We reached out to the Biden campaign for backup, and it passed along the nonpartisan CRS report, which as we said, concluded that â€œthe growth effects tend to show a relatively small (if any) first-year effect on the economy.â€

Bidenâ€™s campaign also pointed to a May 29, 2019, article from Howard Gleckman, a senior fellow in the Urban-Brookings Tax Policy Center, who wrote that the CRS report findings were consistent with the Tax Policy Center prediction in December 2017 that the â€œshort-term macroeconomic effectsâ€ would be â€œextremely modest.â€

â€œIn fairness, the tax cuts didnâ€™t occur in a vacuum,â€ Gleckman wrote in that same article. â€œSome of their benefits may have been offset by President Trumpâ€™s own highly restrictive trade policy, or magnified by new deficit spending approved by Congress in 2018.â€

In his latest update about the economic impact of the TCJA, published on Feb. 5, Gleckman concluded after looking at two years of data: â€œDespite the Trump Administrationâ€™s rosy promises that the post-TCJA economy would boom, it has instead grown on many dimensions at roughly the same steady, unspectacular pace as it did prior to passage of the tax law.â€

â€œOur forecast at the time the TCJA became law was for a modest short-term bump in economic output (mostly from people spending their tax cuts) followed by a gradual return to pre-TCJA trend,â€ Gleckman told us via email. â€œThat is pretty much what happened. â€¦ Business investment fell after passage. Employment pretty much tracked pre-TCJA trends. GDP growth had its bump, then returned to trend.â€

â€œRemember too that the growth story the White House told was this: The TCJA would encourage more capital investment that would lead to more productivity and, eventually, to higher wages,â€ Gleckman said. â€œThe reality was: We never even got the first step, except for a brief period just before and after passage of the law.â€

Gleckman acknowledged, however, that it is â€œimpossible to pull apart tax policy from other issues, including Trumpâ€™s trade policy in 2018 and 2019.â€ It is possible, he said, that the â€œTCJA contributed to more growth but that benefit was offset by the tariffs (which are a tax increase on US consumers and businesses). Or not.â€

â€œThe disruptions of 2020 mean we never will know the long-term effects of the TCJA,â€ Gleckman said. â€œBut based on what we saw in 2018 and 2019, there is no evidence that the TCJA contributed very much to economic growth.â€

Those analyses â€” from CRS and the Tax Policy Center, which is not a conservative group â€” provide some ammunition for Bidenâ€™s claim that the TCJA â€œgenerated virtually no growth at all.â€ Thatâ€™s his assessment, and some economists agree.

But Biden is wrong to claim that â€œmost of the conservative think tanksâ€ agree.

Bidenâ€™s campaign cited three articles that it says came from conservative institutions: two from the American Enterprise Institute and one from the Tax Foundation. None of them support Bidenâ€™s claim, though.

The article from Nicole Kaeding, then at the Tax Foundation, was titled â€œThe Tax Cuts and Jobs Act After A Yearâ€ and was published on Dec. 17, 2018.

Kaeding wrote that one year after the lawâ€™s passage there was â€œvery littleâ€ evidence â€œwe point to on how the Act has impacted the U.S economy.â€ But Kaeding also wrote that â€œthe lawâ€™s design is such that the economic impacts are long-run. It takes several years for the lower cost of capital to impact investment. Firms need time to plan, purchase, and permit new investments before they put the items into service. As we noted in our original score, much of the acceleration of growth happens several years after the lawâ€™s original passage, before fading as provisions in the law expire.â€

Garrett Watson, a senior policy analyst at the Tax Foundation, said Biden is distorting the Tax Foundationâ€™s position.

â€œOur position is not that the TCJA â€˜has generated no growth at all,â€™ but rather that identifying the specific impact the TCJA had on growth is challenging given the many other factors at play that drive business investment and economic growth,â€ Watson told us via email. â€œThis includes the economic headwinds produced by the escalating trade war in 2019 and the coronavirus pandemic today. This is in addition to the fact that it may take several years to isolate the impact of a tax change, as Nicole pointed out in her piece. We provided feedback on a Congressional Research Service (CRS) report on TCJA last year, for example, arguing that â€˜its conclusion that the TCJA has produced little to no increase in output (GDP) and its argument that investment has not increased as was expectedâ€¦are too strong given the evidence.â€™â€

The first article from the American Enterprise Institute cited by the Biden campaign was one written by Alan Viard, a resident scholar at AEI. Although Viard wrote that â€œa sharp uptick in investment has not occurred,â€ he did not conclude that the TCJA has generated no growth.

Rather, Viard posed three possibilities, only one of which considers the possibility that â€œthe corporate tax cut is not boosting investment.â€ It is also possible, he wrote, that â€œthe boost is taking longer than expectedâ€ or that â€œthe tax cut boosted investment relative to what it would otherwise have been, even as other factors (perhaps other TCJA provisions or the trade war) have offset the boost.â€

â€œIt would be very surprising it if didnâ€™t generate any growth at all,â€ Viard told us in a phone interview, adding that as a general economic principle, the corporate tax cuts should increase investment in the U.S.

Viard said that while â€œthe growth impact may be smaller than many of us [conservative economists] thought,â€ it is â€œimpossible to knowâ€ whether the lawâ€™s effects are simply taking longer than expected, or if the growth it generated has been offset by other factors, such as the trade war.

The third article cited by the Biden campaign is a blog post written for AEI by Jason Furman. But Furman is not affiliated with AEI. Furman, an economics professor at Harvard and a nonresident senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, served eight years as a top economic adviser to President Barack Obama. According to Viard, Furman was simply invited to participate in a blog symposium about the effects of the TCJA. The symposium sought to include input from economists across the ideological spectrum.

Wrong on Heritage Foundation

As for Bidenâ€™s specific claim that â€œeven places like the Heritage Foundation said that [TCJA] didnâ€™t grow the economy,â€ the Biden campaign did not get back to us with backup for that.

But the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank, says thatâ€™s false.

On Twitter, Adam Michel, a senior policy analyst who focuses on tax policy for the Heritage Foundation, pointed to his Dec. 12 commentary â€œHow 2 Years of Tax Cuts Have Supported Our Strong Economy.â€

When Biden said something similar last August, Michel tweeted, â€œI think Iâ€™ve written something basically every week for the last year+ that says the tax cuts are working.â€

In a series of tweets, Jessica Anderson, executive director of Heritage Action, the lobbying arm of Heritage, also took issue with Bidenâ€™s comments, saying, â€œThe country saw increased wage growth, business investment, and employment thanks to the law.â€

In a Nov. 4 post, the Peter G. Peterson Foundation looked at what economists from various viewpoints were saying about the TCJA nearly two years after its implementation. One of its conclusions: â€œEconomists do not agree on the economic effects of the TCJA.â€ Additionally, it concludes, â€œeconomists generally agree that while certain definitive trends are emerging, it is impossible to undertake a full accounting of the TCJAâ€™s effects until more time has passed.â€

â€œA full analysis of the effects of the TCJA will not be possible to complete for years to come, if ever,â€ the Peterson report states.

Biden is, of course, entitled to his opinion about the effect of the TCJA. And he has numerous economists he could cite who agree the tax cuts have, to date, resulted in very little economic growth. But he is wrong when he says that â€œmost of the conservative think tanksâ€ in general, and the Heritage Foundation in particular, agree that the tax cuts resulted in â€œvirtually no growth.â€ In fact, they do not agree.

Editorâ€™s note: FactCheck.org does not accept advertising. We rely on grants and individual donations from people like you. Please consider a donation. Credit card donations may be made through our â€œDonateâ€ page. If you prefer to give by check, send to: FactCheck.org, Annenberg Public Policy Center, 202 S. 36th St., Philadelphia, PA 19104.

articles.title: Meme Spreads Wrong Photo, Details in Floyd Criminal Case
articles.text:
Quick Take

A meme misrepresents a 2007 criminal case in Houston involving George Floyd. The meme distorts the details of Floydâ€™s case and includes a photo of a woman who was badly injured in an unrelated attack in Spain in 2018.

Full Story

A popular meme has misrepresented a criminal case involving George Floyd more than a decade ago.

Floydâ€™s death in police custody on May 25 sparked nationwide protests against racism and police violence, which has made the incident a target for misinformation since then.

Now a meme with a photo of a womanâ€™s bruised and bloody face is circulating on social media with this claim: â€œAracely Henriquez was the woman kidnapped and brutally beaten by George #Floyd and his five accomplices, as they searched her home for drugs and money. She was pregnant at the time, and he asked her if she wanted him to kill her baby.â€

But the woman pictured is not Aracely Henriquez. The photo actually shows Andrea Sicignano, an American student who was raped and beaten in Madrid, Spain, in 2018.

In a June 12 post on Facebook, Sicignano wrote, â€œToday my photo is being used as political propaganda/click bait to make people believe that George Floyd deserved to die.â€ She asked that those who see her photo being used that way report it to Facebook and correct the person who shared it.

The photo, Sicignano explained in her recent post, was taken at the hospital after she was attacked. She posted it on Facebook shortly after the attack, and the picture was later published in a Spanish newspaper, which is likely where it was taken from for the meme.

Beyond the use of the picture, the meme gets other parts of the claim wrong, too.

Hereâ€™s whatâ€™s true about the case:

Floyd pleaded guilty in 2009 to aggravated robbery with a deadly weapon. He was not charged with kidnapping or assault.

According to the complaint in the case, filed in 2007, Floyd was one of six men who forced his way into the Houston home that Aracely Henriquez shared with Angel Negrete and a 1-year-old child.

One of the men claimed to be from the water department in order to get Henriquez to open the door. Then Floyd, who was described as the biggest of the men who pulled up in a black Ford Explorer, forced his way in and â€œplaced a pistol against the complainantâ€™s abdomen, and forced her into the living room,â€ the complaint says. It doesnâ€™t say whether or not Henriquez was pregnant.

Floyd then searched the house while another man guarded Henriquez. That man hit her in the â€œhead and side areasâ€ with his pistol after she â€œscreamed for help,â€ the complaint says.

So, while Floyd did plead guilty to a charge stemming from the invasion of Henriquezâ€™s home, the picture circulating with the claim doesnâ€™t show Henriquez and the claim distorts the details of the case.

Editorâ€™s note: FactCheck.org is one of several organizations working with Facebook to debunk misinformation shared on social media. Our previous stories can be found here.

Sources

FactCheck.org. â€œFalsehoods Follow George Floydâ€™s Death.â€ 29 May 2020.

Galloway, Heather. â€œAmerican student attacked and raped in Madrid neighborhood of Aluche.â€ ElPais.com. 26 Dec 2018.

Sicignano, Andrea. Facebook post. 12 Jun 2020.
